elements.content: The reactions of three structurally related flexible pyridyl dithioether ligands, 1,2-bis(4-pyridylthio)ethane (L ), 1,3-bis(4-pyridylthio)propane (L ), and 1,5-bis(4-pyridylthio)pentane (L ), with Mn(ClO4)2·6H2O, Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O, Co(ClO4)2·6H2O, and Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O led to the formation of four new complexes:  {[Mn(L 1 )2(H2O)2](L 1 )2(ClO4)2(CHCl3)2}∞ (1), {[Cd(L 2 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2(H2O)3}∞ (2), {[Co(L 3 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2(H2O)3}2 (3), and {[Zn(L 3 )2(H2O)2](ClO4)2(H2O)3}2 (4), which have been characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray crystallography. Single-crystal X-ray analyses show that complex 1 is a unique one-dimensional chain containing cage unit, 2 is a double-stranded chain structure, and 3 and 4 are binuclear cage molecules. In the complexes, all the ligands adopt N,N-bidentate bridging coordination mode using the two pyridyl nitrogens to coordinate to metal centers. In complexes 1 and 2, the uncoordinated sulfur atoms show interchain weak S···S interactions, by which two 1-D chains are linked to two different 2-D supramolecular networks. Additional weak C−H···O hydrogen bonds further connect complex 1 into a 3-D supramolecular architecture. These S···S contacts and C−H···O hydrogen bonds also help to stabilize the crystal structures of these complexes.

In the complexes, all the ligands adopt N,N-bidentate bridging coordination mode using the two pyridyl nitrogens to coordinate to metal centers. In complexes 1 and 2, the uncoordinated sulfur atoms show interchain weak S⋅⋅⋅S interactions, by which two 1-D chains are linked to two different 2-D supramolecular networks. Additional weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds further connect complex 1 into a 3-D supramolecular architecture. These S⋅⋅⋅S contacts and C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds also help to stabilize the crystal structures of these complexes.

elements.content: Four novel complexes of pyridyl dithioether ligands with MnII, CdII, CoII, and ZnII have been synthesized and characterized, and the coordination properties of the ligands were investigated by experimental and computational methods. Complexes 1 and 2 are one-dimensional polymers, and complexes 3 and 4 are two discrete molecular cages. We found that S···S contacts exist in complexes 1 and 2 and O−H···N and C−H···O hydrogen bonds in 1, and these weak interactions link two low-dimensional complexes into high-dimensional supramolecular coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: Four novel complexes of pyridyl dithioether ligands with MnII, CdII, CoII, and ZnII have been synthesized and characterized, and the coordination properties of the ligands were investigated by experimental and computational methods. Complexes 1 and 2 are one-dimensional polymers, and complexes 3 and 4 are two discrete molecular cages. We found that S⋅⋅⋅S contacts exist in complexes 1 and 2 and O-H⋅⋅⋅N and C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds in 1, and these weak interactions link two low-dimensional complexes into high-dimensional supramolecular coordination polymers.

elements.content: There has been current significant interest in the rational design and synthesis of new discrete or polymeric metal−organic coordination architectures for their potential use as functional materials. The generation of coordination architectures depends mainly on the combination of two factors including the coordination geometry of the metal ions and the nature of the ligands. Therefore, the use of a well-designed ligand to control the assembly of supramolecular architectures has become a popular and rapidly growing discipline. Previously, the development of multidimensional networks based primarily on linking metal centers with rigid bridging components, such as 4,4‘-bipyridine, has been extensively investigated. Recently, increasing attention has been paid to the use of flexible bridging units in the construction of supramolecular architectures, and this approach is attractive because the flexibility and conformational freedoms of such ligands offer the possibility for the construction of unprecedented frameworks. However, due to less predictability of the coordination architectures self-assembled by such ligands and metal centers, there is still a very long way to go to develop new metal−organic coordination architectures using flexible spacer ligands to rationalize the design of compounds with well-defined structures and useful functions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been current significant interest in the rational design and synthesis of new discrete or polymeric metal-organic coordination architectures for their potential use as functional materials. The generation of coordination architectures depends mainly on the combination of two factors including the coordination geometry of the metal ions and the nature of the ligands. Therefore, the use of a well-designed ligand to control the assembly of supramolecular architectures has become a popular and rapidly growing discipline. Previously, the development of multidimensional networks based primarily on linking metal centers with rigid bridging components, such as 4,4‘-bipyridine, has been extensively investigated. Recently, increasing attention has been paid to the use of flexible bridging units in the construction of supramolecular architectures, and this approach is attractive because the flexibility and conformational freedoms of such ligands offer the possibility for the construction of unprecedented frameworks. However, due to less predictability of the coordination architectures self-assembled by such ligands and metal centers, there is still a very long way to go to develop new metal-organic coordination architectures using flexible spacer ligands to rationalize the design of compounds with well-defined structures and useful functions.

elements.content: In our previous works, 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands with flexible spacers (Scheme a) have been successfully used to construct various structures of complexes including discrete molecules and one-dimensional (1-D) and two-dimensional (2-D) coordination polymers. As a continuing investigation on the coordination properties of flexible spacer ligands, we designed three structurally related flexible 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands, 1,2-bis(4-pyridylthio)ethane (L 1 ), 1,3-bis(4-pyridylthio)propane (L 2 ), and 1,5-bis(4-pyridylthio)pentane (L 3 ) (Scheme b). Herein, we report the construction of four novel MnII, CdII, CoII, and ZnII coordination architectures with the three ligands. Crystallographic data and experimental details for structural analyses of the four complexes are summarized in Table .

Compounds 1−4 were prepared by the reaction of the corresponding metal perchlorate salts and equamolar neutral dithioether ligands under similar conditions. Complex 1 has 1:4 metal/ligand composition, and for complexes 2−4, 1:2 metal/ligand ratios were achieved, although all the four complexes were prepared using 1:1 metal/ligand molar ratio. Indeed, complexes 1−4 can be isolated using 1:1, 1:2, or 1:6 metal/ligand reaction stoichiometries, which was confirmed by X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, and elemental analyses, indicating that the complex structures obtained by this reaction are not sensitive to the metal/ligand ratios. We had tried to investigate the effects of counterions on the structures of complexes through the reaction of L 3 with Co(NO3)2, CoCl2, or CoSO4, but single crystals of the complexes had not been obtained. Therefore, the ClO4 - anion probably plays an important template role in the formation of complex 3. In the IR spectra of complexes 1−4, the broad band centered at ca. 3400 cm-1 indicates the O−H stretching of the aqua molecules. The absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings for all four complexes appear in the 1400−1602 cm-1 region. The strong absorption band appearing in the 700−820 cm-1 region can be assigned to the C−S stretching vibration. The bands of ClO4 - appear near 1100 and 620 cm-1 for the four complexes. It should be noted that due to the coordination of the ligands, the strong absorption band appearing at ∼1575 cm-1 resulted from the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings blue-shifted to ∼1600 cm-1.

Results and Discussion

Compounds 1-4 were prepared by the reaction of the corresponding metal perchlorate salts and equamolar neutral dithioether ligands under similar conditions. Complex 1 has 1:4 metal/ligand composition, and for complexes 2-4, 1:2 metal/ligand ratios were achieved, although all the four complexes were prepared using 1:1 metal/ligand molar ratio. Indeed, complexes 1-4 can be isolated using 1:1, 1:2, or 1:6 metal/ligand reaction stoichiometries, which was confirmed by X-ray  diffraction, IR spectra, and elemental analyses, indicating that the complex structures obtained by this reaction are not sensitive to the metal/ligand ratios. We had tried to investigate the effects of counterions on the structures of complexes through the reaction of L  3   with Co(NO3)2, CoCl2, or CoSO4, but single crystals of the complexes had not been obtained. Therefore, the ClO4 - anion probably plays an important template role in the formation of complex 3. In the IR spectra of complexes 1-4, the broad band centered at ca. 3400 cm-1 indicates the O-H stretching of the aqua molecules. The absorption bands resulting from the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings for all four complexes appear in the 1400-1602 cm-1 region. The strong absorption band appearing in the 700-820 cm-1 region can be assigned to the C-S stretching vibration. The bands of ClO4 - appear near 1100 and 620 cm-1 for the four complexes. It should be noted that due to the coordination of the ligands, the strong absorption band appearing at ~1575 cm-1 resulted from the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings blue-shifted to ~1600 cm-1.

elements.content: {[Mn(L 1 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ](L 1 ) 2 (ClO 4 ) 2 (CHCl 3 ) 2 } ∞ (1). Complex 1 is made up of one-dimensional (1-D) {[Mn(L 1 )2(H2O)2]2+}∞ cationic chains, solvated L 1 molecules, uncoordinated ClO4 - anions, and CHCl3 molecules. Each MnII center is six-coordinated by four pyridyl nitrogens from different ligands and two aqua ligands showing octahedral coordination geometry with the four nitrogen atoms in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atoms of the water molecules locating at the axial positions. The Mn−N (average length is 2.311 Å) and Mn−O (2.169 Å) bond lengths are in the expected range for such coordination bonds (Table ). The cis bond angles around the MnII center are in the range from 83.26(14)° to 96.74(14)°. The coordinated pyridyl rings in the symmetry positions are parallel to each other, while the neighboring coordinated pyridyl rings are inclined to each other with a 66.9° dihedral angle.

Complex 1 includes two kinds of L 1 :  coordinated and uncoordinated ones. The coordinated L 1 adopts N,N-bidentate bridging coordination mode using pyridyl nitrogens to coordinate to MnII centers forming a 1-D chain (Figure a). The basic unit of the chain is the 26-membered parallelogram formed by two ligands and two MnII centers, and the lengths (the distance of two MnII atoms) of two diagonal lines of the parallelogram are 13.266 and 10.181 Å, respectively. It is interesting to observe that the O−H···N hydrogen bonds are formed between the trans-related aqua ligands in the basal positions and solvated L 1 molecules resulting in a 1-D chain containing cage unit. As shown in Figure a, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of the ligand serve as the acceptors to form two kinds of O−H···N hydrogen bonds with aqua ligands. The O···N distances (2.730 and 2.789 Å) and the O−H···N angles (153.3° and 174.5°) fall into the normal range of strong hydrogen bond interactions. The CHCl3 molecules may have played template roles to fill each cage and further stabilize the structure. To date, various cage structures were synthesized and characterized by X-ray diffraction analysis, and most such cage structures were assembled through organic ligands and metal centers only by coordination bonds. However, complex 1 described here is a peculiar cage-containing chain self-assembled by a combination of coordination and hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: A striking feature of complex 1 is the stacking pattern in the solid state. Investigation on the packing diagram of 1 shows that there exist S···S weak interactions between cage-containing chains, and these S···S weak interactions link the 1-D chains into a 2-D network (Figure b). The interchain S···S distance of 3.632 Å is somewhat shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of the two S atoms (3.70 Å), indicating the presence of weak interchain S···S contacts. In the past two decades, short S···S contacts ranging from 3.257−3.675 Å were found to exist extensively in sulfur-rich organic ligands [such as TTF (tetrathiafulvalene) and its derivatives] and their complexes, and it is proved that intermolecular S···S contacts play an essential role to form a conduction band similar to the case of organic conductors based on TTF-like π donor molecules. However, the thioether ligand L 1 has fewer S atoms compared to the sulfur-rich TTF and its derivates. The present complex 1 is a good example that there exist weak intermolecular S···S contacts in the complexes of thioether ligands.

elements.content: Another interesting feature of 1 is the 3-D network, formed by the parallel stacking of the adjacent layers. The 2-D layers formed by 1-D cage-containing chains via S···S weak interactions are stacked as offset mode and the ClO4 - counterions are sandwiched between two layers and hydrogen-bonded to the pyridyl rings of the ligands. The hydrogen atoms from the pyridine rings have been activated by the positive charge due to the coordination of nitrogen atoms to the MnII centers or due to the formations of O−H···N hydrogen bonds, and three O atoms of the uncoordinated ClO4 - anions form the acceptors of three kinds of C−H···O intermolecular hydrogen bonds (Figure c), which link the 2-D layers to form a 3-D supramolecular structure (Figure d). The C···O distances and C−H···O angles are within the ranges 3.257−3.357 Å and 139.3°−171.0°, respectively, falling into the normal range of weak hydrogen bond interactions.

elements.content: {[Cd(L 2 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 (H 2 O) 3 } ∞ (2). Complex 2 is a double-strip 1-D chain structure comprised of {[Cd(L 2 )2(H2O)2]2+}∞ cationic chains (Figure a), uncoordinated ClO4 - anions, and free H2O molecules. In the {[Cd(L 2 )2(H2O)2]2+}∞ cationic chain, each CdII center is also six-coordinated by four pyridyl nitrogens from different ligands and two aqua ligands showing octahedral coordination geometry with the four nitrogen atoms in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atoms of the aqua ligands locating at the axial positions. Two Cd−N distances are different with the bond length of Cd(1)−N(1) [2.341(5) Å] being a little longer than that of Cd(1)−N(2) [2.318(5) Å]. The Cd−N and Cd−O bond lengths (Table ) are in the expected range for such coordination bonds. The cis bond angles around the CdII center are in the range from 89.58(17)° to 90.42(17)°, only deviating from 90° by 0.42°, indicating ideal octahedral coordination geometry of the CdII center. The coordinated pyridyl rings in the symmetry positions are parallel to each other, while the neighboring coordinated pyridyl rings are inclined to each other with an 80.0° dihedral angle.

elements.content: The self-assembly of the supramolecular coordination polymer is the result of a combination of various forces including not only strong and directional interactions (for example, metal−ligand coordination and hydrogen bonds)1-3 but also weak interactions such as π−π stacking, halogen−halogen contacts, and C−H···X (X = O, N, Cl, or I, etc.) contacts. Although the latter supramolecular forces are weaker than the former, they have been recognized to play critical roles in stabilizing and regulating the supramolecular constructs due to their significant contribution to the self-assembly processes. With the development of supramolecular chemistry, there has been an increasing demand to understand various weak interactions by which the molecular building blocks are self-assembled into different aggregation states. The study of weak interactions is of great significance for the development of supramolecular chemistry, and their utilization in the construction of supramolecular coordination polymers has increased. Complexes 1 and 2 are two representative examples of supramolecular compounds self-assembled by combination of strong and directional interactions (coordination and hydrogen bonds) and weak solid-state interactions including C−H···O weak hydrogen bonds and S···S contacts.

elements.content: {[Co(L 3 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 (H 2 O) 3 } 2 (3) and {[Zn(L 3 ) 2 (H 2 O) 2 ](ClO 4 ) 2 (H 2 O) 3 } 2 (4). Complex 3 contains a {[Co(L 3 )2(H2O)2]2+}2 cation cage (Figure ), uncoordinated ClO4 - anions, and H2O molecules. Each CoII center is also six-coordinated by four pyridyl nitrogens from different ligands and two aqua ligands showing octahedral coordination geometry with the four nitrogen atoms in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atoms of H2O locating at the axial positions. The Co−N and Co−O bond lengths (Table ) are in the expected range for such coordination bonds. The cis bond angles around the CoII center are in the range from 88.998(2)° to 90.30(16)° deviating most from 90° by 1.0°. To reduce steric hindrance, the adjacent coordinated pyridyl rings are inclined to each other with the dihedral angle of 65.7°, while the coordinated pyridyl rings in the symmetrical positions are parallel to each other.

elements.content: In our previous works, the reaction of 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands (L) (Scheme a) with AgI salts have obtained various structures of complexes including discrete molecules and 1-D or 2-D network architectures. Therefore, we had also attempted to investigate the coordination features of 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands by the reactions of ligands with AgI salts. However, the reactions of 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands with AgI salts are very fast, and so far, the obtained complexes are always amorphous solid instead of single crystal. In the previous investigation on the coordination chemistry of 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands, the reactions of 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands (L) with transition metal ions of octahedral coordination geometry such as MnII, CoII, NiII, ZnII, and CdII are very difficult, while the reactions of ligands L 1 −L 3 with MnII, CoII, NiII, ZnII, and CdII occur easily. This obviously indicates that the coordination abilities of 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands with transition metal ions of octahedral coordination geometry are stronger than those of 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands (L). To gain a reasonable explanation from electron effect of coordination atoms, the single-point energy calculations based on the geometry of free ligands optimized by Tripos force-field were carried out by the DFT (density functional theory) method using the B3LYP/3-21G basis set in the Gaussian 94 program. The calculated electron distributions of the free 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands are shown in Figure . The calculated results showed that in the 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands the N atoms bear negative charge ranging from 0.5399 to 0.5422, while in the 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands the carried negative charge of N atoms is in the range of 0.5317−0.5642. This indicates that the carried negative charge of N atoms in the two kinds of ligands has no obvious difference; therefore the differences of the coordination abilities of N atoms in the two kinds of ligands cannot be explained by electron effect.

elements.content: The difference of the structures between 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands and 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands is only the position of pyridine N atoms. The pyridine N atoms of 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands locate at the adjacent position of S atoms. Due to the steric hindrance of S atoms of 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands (Scheme a), the coordination ability of the pyridine N atoms is reduced. When the 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands are coordinated with geometrically flexible metal ions such as AgI, stable complexes may be formed through adjusting the geometries of metal ions and ligands. However, when 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands are coordinated with rigid octahedral geometric metal ions, stable complexes are difficult to form only through adjusting the geometries of metal ions. 4-Pyridyl dithioethers are exo-dentate ligands, and the pyridine N atoms have little steric hindrance (Scheme b). When the 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands are coordinated with rigid octahedral geometric metal ions, the ligands can adjust conformation to form stable complexes with rigid octahedral geometric metal ions. Therefore, the difference of coordination ability between 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands and 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands mainly results from the difference of the steric hindrance of the pyridine N atoms.

The MnII, CdII, CoII, and ZnII complexes with three structurally related pyridyl dithioether ligands have been investigated by experimental and calculation methods. Although the three ligands are very similar in structure and adopt similar coordination modes, they form quite different coordination architectures with these metal ions. The coordination ability of the 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands seems to be stronger than that of the 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands, probably due to the difference of steric hindrance of pyridine N atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The MnII, CdII, CoII, and ZnII complexes with three structurally related pyridyl dithioether ligands have been investigated by experimental and calculation methods. Although the three ligands are very similar in structure and adopt similar coordination modes, they form quite different coordination architectures with these metal ions. The coordination ability of the 4-pyridyl dithioether ligands seems to be stronger than that of the 2-pyridyl dithioether ligands, probably due to the difference of steric hindrance of pyridine N atoms.

Caution! Although we have met no problems in handling perchlorate salts during this work, these should be treated with great caution owing to their potential explosive nature.

X-ray Crystallography. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite crystal monochromator situated in the incident beam for data collection at room temperature. The determination of unit cell parameters and data collections were performed with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Unit cell dimensions were obtained with least-squares refinements, and all structures were solved by direct methods. Metal atoms in each complex were located from E-maps. The other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses. The final refinement was performed by full matrix least-squares methods with anisotropic thermal parameters for non-hydrogen atoms on F 2. The hydrogen atoms were added theoretically and riding on the concerned atoms. In the structures of 3 and 4, ClO4 - ions are disordered and refined isotropically with constraint. CCDC-240848 (1), -240849 (2), -240850 (3), and -240851 (4) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K.; fax +44-1223-336033; e-mail deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk.

elements.content: Calculation Details. All molecular structures of the free ligands were completely optimized by Tripos force-field geometry optimization using Sybyl6.4 software packages. After optimization for 500 circles using the Powell method, the standard of convergence (the difference of energy is less than 1 cal/mol) was reached for all of the ligands, suggesting a true minimum. The single-point energy calculations based on the geometry of free ligands optimized by Tripos force-field were carried out by the DFT (density functional theory) method using the B3LYP/3-21G basis set in the Gaussian 94 program.
